G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, providing jurisdiction over civil actions of this nature in the Massachusetts District Courts.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease in Massachusetts includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which prohibits landlords from interfering with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of their rental premises.

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes a duty on landlords to provide habitable premises, as established in *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: This opinion (a concurrence/dissent) expressly agrees that Massachusetts should abandon the old rule of no implied duty and instead impose on landlords, at least for dwelling units, an obligation to provide premises that meet minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, enforceable by tenants. Although the author disagrees with the majority’s chosen doctrinal label (“implied warranty of habitability”), he endorses recognizing a landlord duty to maintain habitable premises grounded in statutory and code standards. Thus the case, as a whole, is a leading Massachusetts authority establishing a landlord’s duty to provide habitable premises.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair…’ … As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would … hold instead (a) that the various statutes… prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”}

State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. \u00a7 4.proposition: The mold in the Premises has rendered the bathroom unsafe and unsanitary, in direct contravention of Massachusetts habitability standards and applicable housing codes, such as the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. § 410.750.

*Dolby v. Zorn*, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 570,.raw_text: *Dolby v. Zorn*, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 570, 576 (1996) (Implied Right of Habitability Includes Mold Issues).
*Dolby v. Zorn*, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 570,.proposition: *Dolby v. Zorn*, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 570, 576 (1996) (Implied Right of Habitability Includes Mold Issues).
*Dolby v. Zorn*, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 570,.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Dolby v. Zorn at all; it is an OUI criminal case involving discovery violations (Commonwealth v. Fossa), and it concerns criminal discovery, continuances, and prejudice from late disclosure. It does not mention habitability, landlord–tenant law, or mold, and therefore cannot stand for the proposition that the implied warranty/right of habitability includes mold issues. The citation as given is inaccurate or misattributed for the stated proposition.
*Dolby v. Zorn*, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 570,.relevant_excerpt: We are unable and unwilling, on the present record, see note 3, supra, to discern an abuse of discretion on the part of either the assignment judge or the trial judge in requiring an immediate trial over Fossa’s objection. We are nonetheless troubled by the apparent failure ... of either judge to exercise the substantial discretion each possessed in the circumstances. See Mass.R.Crim.P. 14(c)(1), 378 Mass. 880 (1979). When confronted with the Commonwealth’s failure to comply with its discovery obligations, “the judge may make a further order for discovery, grant a continuance, or enter such other order as he deems just under the circumstances.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).raw_text: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (Interference with Quiet Enjoyment).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982) (Interference with Quiet Enjoyment).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely interprets and applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment to a landlord’s failure to prevent repeated flooding, explicitly analyzing what constitutes an “interference with the quiet enjoyment” of residential premises, the required mental state, available damages, and attorneys’ fees. Although the court ultimately vacates the separate $10,000 quiet-enjoyment damages award as duplicative, it clearly holds that Gem’s conduct constituted an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment under § 14 and discusses that doctrine in depth.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute. …[W]e hold that… Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it… permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”}

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.raw_text: *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (Statutory Damages for Quiet Enjoyment Violations).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: *Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (1991) (Statutory Damages for Quiet Enjoyment Violations).
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The proposition label indicates this case as authority on statutory damages in the context of quiet enjoyment/landlord‑tenant violations. In Haddad, the SJC interprets G.L. c. 93A § 9 after its 1979 amendment to allow recovery of non‑pecuniary, personal‑injury‑type damages (including intentional infliction of emotional distress) and to treat such harms as “actual damages” that are subject to mandatory multiple damages. That is a clear holding on the scope of statutory (including multiplied) damages available for landlord misconduct violating quiet enjoyment and habitability duties.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt: “In 1979… the Legislature amended § 9 (1), and deleted the ‘loss of money or property’ requirement… ‘Any person… who has been injured by another person’s use or employment of any method, act or practice declared to be unlawful by section two… may bring an action… for damages.’… [U]nder the amended version of § 9 (1), the invasion of any legally protected right was compensable. In Maillet… we clarified that this included invasions in the form of injury to the person…. Because severe emotional distress is a form of personal injury… it would seem to follow that it also is compensable under § 9….”

*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 245 (.raw_text: *Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 245 (2013) (Recoverable Emotional Distress Damages).
*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 245 (.proposition: *Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 245 (2013) (Recoverable Emotional Distress Damages).
*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 245 (.support_reasoning: The opinion in Lipsitt v. Plaud concerns whether the Massachusetts Wage Act preempts common-law contract and quasi-contract claims for unpaid wages. It does not address the availability, scope, or recoverability of emotional distress damages at all. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for a proposition about recoverable emotional distress damages.
*Lipsitt v. Plaud*, 466 Mass. 240, 245 (.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we are asked to decide whether G. L. c. 149, §§ 148 and 150 (Wage Act), are intended to be the exclusive remedy for the recovery of unpaid wages under Massachusetts law, preempting common-law breach of contract and related quasi-contract claims. We conclude that they are not.”

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) (Obligation to Maintain Safe Living Conditions).
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: *Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987) (Obligation to Maintain Safe Living Conditions).
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion primarily concerns rent control overcharges, security deposit violations, and whether an oral agreement can shift responsibility for heat and hot water under the State Sanitary Code. While it briefly notes sanitary code violations and a breach of the warranty of habitability, it does not articulate or analyze a general “obligation to maintain safe living conditions” in a way that creates or clarifies such a broad principle. The case is about specific statutory and regulatory compliance, not a freestanding general duty formulation.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
“Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property… The apartment was subject to rent control…

D. Breach of Warranty of Habitability.
Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability… The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations… There is record support for the amount awarded.”

Massachusetts Trial Court Housing Guidel.raw_text: Massachusetts Trial Court Housing Guidelines § 3.02 (Landlord’s Duty to Repair).
Massachusetts Trial Court Housing Guidel.proposition: Massachusetts Trial Court Housing Guidelines § 3.02 (Landlord’s Duty to Repair).

*Armstrong v. United Founders Life Ins..raw_text: *Armstrong v. United Founders Life Ins. Co.*, 383 Mass. 709 (1981) (Tenant's Remedies Against Landlord).
*Armstrong v. United Founders Life Ins..proposition: *Armstrong v. United Founders Life Ins. Co.*, 383 Mass. 709 (1981) (Tenant's Remedies Against Landlord).
*Armstrong v. United Founders Life Ins..support_reasoning: The opinion in Gallant v. Worcester (mis-cited here as Armstrong v. United Founders Life Ins. Co.) concerns municipal liability for defects in public ways, the exclusivity of G.L. c. 84, the interaction with the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act (G.L. c. 258), and wrongful death under G.L. c. 229. It does not concern landlord‑tenant law or tenants’ remedies against landlords. Therefore it does not support the proposition indicated by the parenthetical ‘Tenant’s Remedies Against Landlord.’
*Armstrong v. United Founders Life Ins..relevant_excerpt: “Prior to the enactment of G. L. c. 258, G. L. c. 84 was the exclusive remedy for claims against governmental entities responsible for defects in ways. … By its terms, St. 1978, c. 512, § 18, preserves the exclusivity of G. L. c. 84. … By virtue of the implied repeal of G. L. c. 229, § 1, we rule that the dismissal of Gallant’s action, to the extent that the city argued the limitations of that statute, would not be warranted.”
